results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.
results.question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?

Helpful Answer:

Irish citizenship can be acquired in several ways:

1. By birth: If you were born in Ireland on or after 1 January 2005, you may be an Irish citizen if at least one of your parents was an Irish citizen or was ordinarily resident in the State at the time of your birth.

2. By birth outside Ireland: If you were born outside Ireland on or after 1 January 2005, you may be an Irish citizen if at least one of your parents was an Irish citizen by birth or naturalization, and was born in Ireland or was ordinarily resident in the State for a continuous period of at least three years before your birth.

3. By descent: If you were born outside Ireland, you may be an Irish citizen if your father or mother was an Irish citizen by birth or naturalization, and you were registered as an Irish citizen by the Irish embassy or consulate before your 18th birthday.

4. By naturalization: If you are over 18 years of age, of good character, and have resided in Ireland for a continuous period of five years, you may be eligible for Irish citizenship by naturalization.

For more detailed information, please visit the Citizens Information website: https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/moving_country/moving_to_ireland/irish_citizenship.html
results.answer:
Irish citizenship can be acquired in several ways:

- By birth: If you were born in Ireland on or after 1 January 2005, you may be an Irish citizen if at least one of your parents was an Irish citizen or was ordinarily resident in the State at the time of your birth.

- By birth outside Ireland: If you were born outside Ireland on or after 1 January 2005, you may be an Irish citizen if at least one of your parents was an Irish citizen by birth or naturalization, and was born in Ireland or was ordinarily resident in the State for a continuous period of at least three years before your birth.

- By descent: If you were born outside Ireland, you may be an Irish citizen if your father or mother was an Irish citizen by birth or naturalization, and you were registered as an Irish citizen by the Irish embassy or consulate before your 18th birthday.

- By naturalization: If you are over 18 years of age, of good character, and have resided in Ireland for a continuous period of five years, you may be eligible for Irish citizenship by naturalization.

For more detailed information, please visit the Citizens Information website: https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/moving_country/moving_to_ireland/irish_citizenship.

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.
results.question: What is ordinary residence?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is ordinary residence?

Helpful Answer:

Ordinary residence is a term used in Irish social welfare law to determine a person's entitlement to certain social welfare payments. To be considered ordinarily resident in Ireland, a person must have resided in the State for a certain period of time and must have a substantial connection to the State. This usually means that the person has a home in Ireland, is working or seeking work, and intends to continue living in Ireland.

It's important to note that the length of time required to be considered ordinarily resident can vary depending on the specific social welfare payment in question. For example, to be eligible for Jobseeker's Allowance, a person must have been ordinarily resident in Ireland for the 12 months before making the claim, while for the State Pension, a person must have been ordinarily resident in Ireland for a certain number of years, depending on their age.

If you have any questions about your own eligibility for social welfare payments or need further clarification on the concept of ordinary residence, please don't hesitate to contact the Citizens Information Service. We are here to help!

For example, to be eligible for Jobseeker's Allowance, a person must have been ordinarily resident in Ireland for the 12 months before making the claim, while for the State Pension, a person must have been ordinarily resident in Ireland for a certain number of years, depending on their age.

If you have any questions about your own eligibility for social welfare payments or need further clarification on the concept of ordinary residence, please don't hesitate to contact the Citizens Information Service. We are here to help!

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.
results.question: What counts as genuine redundancy?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

Helpful Answer:

In Ireland, genuine redundancy occurs when an employer needs to reduce the workforce due to a genuine and objective need to do so, such as a closure of the business, a significant reduction in the workload, or a reorganization of the business that results in a need for fewer employees.

To qualify for a genuine redundancy payment, the following conditions must be met:

1. The employee must have been continuously employed for at least 104 weeks (2 years) up to the date of dismissal.
2. The employee must have been dismissed due to genuine redundancy.
3. The employee must not have been offered suitable alternative employment within the organization.
4. The employee must not have refused an offer of suitable alternative employment without a reasonable cause.

If you are unsure about your eligibility for a genuine redundancy payment, you should contact the Citizens Information Service or seek advice from a legal professional.
results.answer:
In Ireland, genuine redundancy occurs when an employer needs to reduce the workforce due to a genuine and objective need to do so, such as a closure of the business, a significant reduction in the workload, or a reorganization of the business that results in a need for fewer employees.

To qualify for a genuine redundancy payment, the following conditions must be met:

- The employee must have been continuously employed for at least 104 weeks (2 years) up to the date of dismissal.
- The employee must have been dismissed due to genuine redundancy.
- The employee must not have been offered suitable alternative employment within the organization.
- The employee must not have refused an offer of suitable alternative employment without a reasonable cause.

If you are unsure about your eligibility for a genuine redundancy payment, you should contact the Citizens Information Service or seek advice from a legal professional.

results.ground_truth: A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. You can apply for a GP visit card online.
results.question: What is a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:

A GP Visit Card is a medical card issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE) in Ireland. It entitles the holder to free GP services, including consultations, prescriptions, and certain medical tests. The card is available to people who meet certain income and means-tested criteria, as well as to certain groups such as children under six, people over 70, and those with specific medical conditions. If you think you may be eligible for a GP Visit Card, you can apply through the HSE's website or by contacting your local health office.

The card is available to people who meet certain income and means-tested criteria, as well as to certain groups such as children under six, people over 70, and those with specific medical conditions. If you think you may be eligible for a GP Visit Card, you can apply through the HSE's website or by contacting your local health office.

results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.
results.question: Who can get a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who can get a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:

A GP Visit Card is a medical card for people who are not eligible for a medical card but need regular medical care from a General Practitioner (GP). To be eligible for a GP Visit Card, you must be over 70 years old, or under 70 years old and in receipt of one of the specified social welfare payments or a specified long-term illness or disability.

Here is a list of the social welfare payments that qualify for a GP Visit Card:

1. Jobseeker's Allowance (Contribution and Non-Contribution)
2. Jobseeker's Benefit
3. One-Parent Family Payment
4. Disability Allowance

6. Invalidity Pension
7. Widow's, Widower's or Surviving Civil Partner's (Contributory) Pension

20. Deserted Wife's Benefit

23. Widow's, Widower's or Surviving Civil Partner's (Jobseeker's) Allowance
24. Widow's, Widower's or Surviving Civil Partner's (Jobseeker's) Benefit
25. Guardian's Payment
26. Half-orphan's Allowance
27. Child Benefit (for a child under 16 years old who is in

results.ground_truth: Online applications are completed in approximately 20 working days for first-time applicants. If you are applying by post, you should allow at least 8 weeks for your application to be processed (not including postage times). This period may be extended at certain times of the year due to increased application numbers. First-time postal applications from the UK take at least 8 weeks. You can check the Passport Service website for current processing times.
results.question: How long will my passport application take?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How long will my passport application take?

Helpful Answer:

The processing time for a passport application in Ireland can vary. If you apply online or by post, it usually takes about 10 working days for a standard passport and 15 working days for an urgent passport. However, during peak times, it may take longer. If you apply in person at a Passport Office, it can be issued on the same day if you have all the necessary documents and pay the urgent fee. For the most accurate and up-to-date information, please visit the official Irish Passport Office website or contact them directly.

If you apply in person at a Passport Office, it can be issued on the same day if you have all the necessary documents and pay the urgent fee. For the most accurate and up-to-date information, please visit the official Irish Passport Office website or contact them directly.

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.
results.question: What is a Police Certificate?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a Police Certificate?

Helpful Answer:

A Police Certificate, also known as a Garda (Police) Certificate in Ireland, is an official document issued by the Garda National Central Bureau (GNCB) that verifies an individual's criminal record or lack thereof. It is often required for visa applications, employment, or immigration purposes in other countries. The certificate includes details of any convictions, cautions, or other relevant information held on the Garda Central Vetting Unit's (GCVU) database. To apply for a Police Certificate, you must complete an application form and provide identification documents. The processing time can vary, but it usually takes around 4-6 weeks. For more detailed information, please visit the official Irish Naturalisation and Immigration Service (INIS) website.

For more detailed information, please visit the official Irish Naturalisation and Immigration Service (INIS) website.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.
results.question: How to register to vote?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How to register to vote?

Helpful Answer:

To register to vote in Ireland, you need to be 18 years old or over, a citizen of Ireland or a citizen of another EU member state, and ordinarily resident in the State. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to register:

1. Fill out the RFA (Register of Electors) form. You can get this form from your local authority's website, a public library, or a Garda (police) station.

2. Fill in your personal details, including your name, address, date of birth, and PPS number (Personal Public Service Number). If you don't have a PPS number, you can still register, but you'll need to provide other forms of identification.

3. Sign and date the form.

4. Send the completed form to your local authority. You can do this by post, in person, or by email (check with your local authority to see if they accept electronic submissions).

5. Your local authority will review your application and send you a letter confirming your registration. If there are any issues with your application, they will contact you.

6. Once registered, you'll be added to the Register of Electors, which is updated annually. You can check if you're on the register by visiting the Check the Register of Electors website (https://www.checktheregister.ie/).

7. Remember to update your details if you move house or change your name.

For more information, visit the Citizens Information website (https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/voting/registering_to_vote.html) or contact your local authority.
results.answer:
To register to vote in Ireland, you need to be 18 years old or over, a citizen of Ireland or a citizen of another EU member state, and ordinarily resident in the State. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to register:

- Fill out the RFA (Register of Electors) form. You can get this form from your local authority's website, a public library, or a Garda (police) station.

- Fill in your personal details, including your name, address, date of birth, and PPS number (Personal Public Service Number). If you don't have a PPS number, you can still register, but you'll need to provide other forms of identification.

- Sign and date the form.

- Send the completed form to your local authority. You can do this by post, in person, or by email (check with your local authority to see if they accept electronic submissions).

- Your local authority will review your application and send you a letter confirming your registration. If there are any issues with your application, they will contact you.

- Once registered, you'll be added to the Register of Electors, which is updated annually. You can check if you're on the register by visiting the Check the Register of Electors website (https://www.checktheregister.ie/).

- Remember to update your details if you move house or change your name.

For more information, visit the Citizens Information website (https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/voting/registering_to_vote.html) or contact your local authority.

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.
results.question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?

Helpful Answer:

The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is a financial assistance program provided by the Irish government to help homeowners refurbish vacant properties that have been empty for at least one year. The grant aims to bring these properties back into use, thereby addressing housing shortages and improving neighborhoods.

The grant covers a maximum of 90% of eligible works, up to a maximum of €30,000. Eligible works include repair and renovation works, such as roofing, plumbing, electrical, and heating systems, as well as works to make the property suitable for habitation, such as painting, flooring, and plastering.

To be eligible for the grant, the property must be a residential dwelling, and the applicant must be the owner of the property and the person responsible for the works. The property must also be located in an area designated as a housing pressure area by the local authority.

Applications for the grant are made through the local authority, and the grant is paid in stages, with the final payment made upon completion of the works and inspection by the local authority. For more detailed information, you can visit the Citizens Information website or contact your local authority.
results.answer:

The grant aims to bring these properties back into use, thereby addressing housing shortages and improving neighborhoods.

The grant covers a maximum of 90% of eligible works, up to a maximum of €30,000. Eligible works include repair and renovation works, such as roofing, plumbing, electrical, and heating systems, as well as works to make the property suitable for habitation, such as painting, flooring, and plastering.

To be eligible for the grant, the property must be a residential dwelling, and the applicant must be the owner of the property and the person responsible for the works. The property must also be located in an area designated as a housing pressure area by the local authority.

Applications for the grant are made through the local authority, and the grant is paid in stages, with the final payment made upon completion of the works and inspection by the local authority. For more detailed information, you can visit the Citizens Information website or contact your local authority.

results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but this is subject to a number of conditions. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.
results.question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?

Helpful Answer:

Employers in Ireland have the right to require employees to take annual leave, but they must give at least twice as much notice as the length of the leave they are requesting. For example, if your employer wants you to take a week off, they must give you at least two weeks' notice.

However, there are some exceptions to this rule. If you have less than 12 months of service with your employer, they can require you to take annual leave if it suits their business needs, as long as they give you the required notice.

Additionally, your employer cannot force you to take annual leave if it would result in you not being able to take your full annual leave entitlement for the year, unless you agree to it.

If you have any concerns about your employer requiring you to take annual leave, you should contact the Workplace Relations Commission for advice.
results.answer:
Employers in Ireland have the right to require employees to take annual leave, but they must give at least twice as much notice as the length of the leave they are requesting. For example, if your employer wants you to take a week off, they must give you at least two weeks' notice.

However, there are some exceptions to this rule. If you have less than 12 months of service with your employer, they can require you to take annual leave if it suits their business needs, as long as they give you the required notice.

Additionally, your employer cannot force you to take annual leave if it would result in you not being able to take your full annual leave entitlement for the year, unless you agree to it.

If you have any concerns about your employer requiring you to take annual leave, you should contact the Workplace Relations Commission for advice.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.
results.question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?

Helpful Answer:

If you get sick while on annual leave, you should follow the sick leave procedures provided by your employer. In general, you will need to inform your employer as soon as possible and provide a medical certificate from a doctor to confirm your illness.

It's important to note that the entitlement to annual leave is separate from the entitlement to sick leave. However, if you have used up all your sick leave entitlement before taking your annual leave, you may still be entitled to take your annual leave, even if you become sick during that time.

If you are unsure about your employer's sick leave or annual leave policies, you should contact your employer or seek advice from a trade union or the Workplace Relations Commission.

For more information on annual leave and sick leave, you can visit the Citizens Information website at:

* Annual Leave: <https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/employment/annual_leave/>
* Sick Leave: <https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/employment/sick_leave/>
results.answer:
If you get sick while on annual leave, you should follow the sick leave procedures provided by your employer. In general, you will need to inform your employer as soon as possible and provide a medical certificate from a doctor to confirm your illness.

It's important to note that the entitlement to annual leave is separate from the entitlement to sick leave. However, if you have used up all your sick leave entitlement before taking your annual leave, you may still be entitled to take your annual leave, even if you become sick during that time.

If you are unsure about your employer's sick leave or annual leave policies, you should contact your employer or seek advice from a trade union or the Workplace Relations Commission.

For more information on annual leave and sick leave, you can visit the Citizens Information website at:

* Annual Leave: <https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/employment/annual_leave/>

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially
results.question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?

Helpful Answer:

In Ireland, a tenant can end a tenancy after the first 6 months for a valid reason. Some valid reasons include:

1. Moving out due to a change in personal circumstances, such as getting a job in another location, getting married, or having a baby.
2. The landlord needs the property for their own use or a close family member, but only if the landlord has given you written notice at least 28 days before the end of the tenancy.
3. The property is being sold, but only if the new owner intends to live there themselves and has given you written notice at least 28 days before the end of the tenancy.
4. The property is being substantially renovated, but only if the landlord has given you written notice at least 28 days before the end of the tenancy and the work will take more than 4 weeks to complete.
5. The tenant has breached the terms of the tenancy agreement, such as not paying rent on time, causing damage to the property, or using the property for illegal activities.

It's important to note that a tenant cannot be evicted without a valid reason and proper notice being given. If you are a tenant and your landlord wants to end the tenancy, they must follow the correct procedures and give you the required notice. If you are a landlord, it's important to understand your rights and responsibilities when ending a tenancy.

For more information, you can visit the Citizens Information website at <https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/housing/renting_a_home/ending_a_tenancy.html> or contact your local Citizens Information Centre.
results.answer:
In Ireland, a tenant can end a tenancy after the first 6 months for a valid reason. Some valid reasons include:

- Moving out due to a change in personal circumstances, such as getting a job in another location, getting married, or having a baby.
- The landlord needs the property for their own use or a close family member, but only if the landlord has given you written notice at least 28 days before the end of the tenancy.
- The property is being sold, but only if the new owner intends to live there themselves and has given you written notice at least 28 days before the end of the tenancy.
- The property is being substantially renovated, but only if the landlord has given you written notice at least 28 days before the end of the tenancy and the work will take more than 4 weeks to complete.
- The tenant has breached the terms of the tenancy agreement, such as not paying rent on time, causing damage to the property, or using the property for illegal activities.

It's important to note that a tenant cannot be evicted without a valid reason and proper notice being given. If you are a tenant and your landlord wants to end the tenancy, they must follow the correct procedures and give you the required notice. If you are a landlord, it's important to understand your rights and responsibilities when ending a tenancy.

For more information, you can visit the Citizens Information website at <https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/housing/renting_a_home/ending_a_tenancy.html> or contact your local Citizens Information Centre.

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.
results.question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Helpful Answer:

When an order is delayed or not delivered, the consumer has certain rights under Irish consumer protection law. Here are some steps you can take:

1. Contact the seller: Reach out to the seller or retailer as soon as possible to inform them about the issue. They may be able to provide an explanation or a solution.

2. Check the terms and conditions: Review the terms and conditions of your purchase, as they may outline the seller's delivery policy and any rights you have in case of a delay or non-delivery.

3. Request a refund or replacement: If the seller is unable to resolve the issue or if the delay is unreasonable, you may be entitled to a refund or a replacement.

4. Contact the e-commerce platform (if applicable): If you purchased the item through an online marketplace, such as Amazon or eBay, you can also contact their customer service for assistance.

5. Report the issue to the Competition and Consumer Protection Commission (CCPC): If the seller fails to address your concerns, you can file a complaint with the CCPC. You can do this online at www.ccpc.ie or by calling their helpline at 1890 432 432.

6. Small Claims Court: If the value of the item is less than €2,000, you can bring the matter to the Small Claims Court. The court can help you recover the money owed to you.
results.answer:
When an order is delayed or not delivered, the consumer has certain rights under Irish consumer protection law. Here are some steps you can take:

- Contact the seller: Reach out to the seller or retailer as soon as possible to inform them about the issue. They may be able to provide an explanation or a solution.

- Check the terms and conditions: Review the terms and conditions of your purchase, as they may outline the seller's delivery policy and any rights you have in case of a delay or non-delivery.

- Request a refund or replacement: If the seller is unable to resolve the issue or if the delay is unreasonable, you may be entitled to a refund or a replacement.

- Contact the e-commerce platform (if applicable): If you purchased the item through an online marketplace, such as Amazon or eBay, you can also contact their customer service for assistance.

- Report the issue to the Competition and Consumer Protection Commission (CCPC): If the seller fails to address your concerns, you can file a complaint with the CCPC. You can do this online at www.ccpc.ie or by calling their helpline at 1890 432 432.

- Small Claims Court: If the value of the item is less than €2,000, you can bring the matter to the Small Claims Court. The court can help you recover the money owed to you.

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.
results.question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:

In Ireland, adoption can be carried out by married couples, single people over the age of 25, and civil partners. The adopters must be at least 18 years old, and there are no upper age limits. However, the Adoption Authority of Ireland will consider the applicant's health, lifestyle, and ability to provide a stable home environment for the child. Additionally, the applicants must undergo a home study assessment and meet certain criteria, such as having a spare bedroom for the child and being of good character. It's important to note that the child's best interests are the primary consideration in all adoption decisions. For more detailed information, please visit the Adoption Authority of Ireland's website or contact them directly.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.
results.question: How do penalty points work?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How do penalty points work?

Helpful Answer:

Penalty points are a system used in Ireland to discourage road traffic offences. If you commit a traffic offence, you may receive penalty points on your driving licence. The number of points you receive depends on the severity of the offence.

Here's a breakdown of the most common offences and their corresponding penalty points:

1. Speeding (exceeding the speed limit by more than 24km/h but less than 40km/h): 3 points
2. Speeding (exceeding the speed limit by 40km/h or more): 5 points
3. Failing to wear a seatbelt: 3 points
4. Using a mobile phone while driving: 3 points
5. Not wearing a helmet on a motorcycle: 3 points
6. Driving without due care and attention: 2-6 points
7. Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs: Minimum 10 points, and a possible disqualification from driving
8. Failing to stop at a red light: 4 points
9. Failing to stop at a stop sign: 2 points
10. Driving without insurance: 5 points, and a possible disqualification from driving

If you accumulate 12 or more penalty points within a three-year period, your driving licence will be suspended for a period of six months. If you accumulate 15 or more points within a two-year period, your driving licence will be suspended for a period of two years.

It's important to note that if you receive a fixed charge notice for a traffic offence, you have the option to pay the fine or contest the charge in court. If you choose to contest the charge, you will have the opportunity to explain your side of the story and present any evidence you may have.

For more information on penalty points, including a full list of offences and their corresponding penalty points, please visit the official website of the Road Safety Authority at <https://www.rsa.ie/en/Road-Safety/Driver-Licensing/Penalty-Points-and-Disqualification/>.
results.answer:

- Speeding (exceeding the speed limit by more than 24km/h but less than 40km/h): 3 points
- Speeding (exceeding the speed limit by 40km/h or more): 5 points
- Failing to wear a seatbelt: 3 points
- Using a mobile phone while driving: 3 points
- Not wearing a helmet on a motorcycle: 3 points
- Driving without due care and attention: 2-6 points
- Driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs: Minimum 10 points, and a possible disqualification from driving
- Failing to stop at a red light: 4 points
- Failing to stop at a stop sign: 2 points
10. Driving without insurance: 5 points, and a possible disqualification from driving

If you accumulate 12 or more penalty points within a three-year period, your driving licence will be suspended for a period of six months. If you accumulate 15 or more points within a two-year period, your driving licence will be suspended for a period of two years.

It's important to note that if you receive a fixed charge notice for a traffic offence, you have the option to pay the fine or contest the charge in court. If you choose to contest the charge, you will have the opportunity to explain your side of the story and present any evidence you may have.

For more information on penalty points, including a full list of offences and their corresponding penalty points, please visit the official website of the Road Safety Authority at <https://www.rsa.ie/en/Road-Safety/Driver-Licensing/Penalty-Points-and-Disqualification/>.

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.
results.question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?

Helpful Answer:

In Ireland, if you are an employee who has been continuously employed for 10 years or more, and you are made redundant, you are entitled to statutory redundancy pay. The amount of pay depends on your age, length of service, and weekly pay.

If you have been employed for less than 10 years, you may still be entitled to a payment, but it will depend on the terms of your contract and any redundancy policy your employer has in place.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Citizens Information website (www.citizensinformation.ie) and search for "Redundancy Pay". You can also contact the National Redundancy Helpline on 1890 80 80 90.
results.answer:
In Ireland, if you are an employee who has been continuously employed for 10 years or more, and you are made redundant, you are entitled to statutory redundancy pay. The amount of pay depends on your age, length of service, and weekly pay.

If you have been employed for less than 10 years, you may still be entitled to a payment, but it will depend on the terms of your contract and any redundancy policy your employer has in place.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Citizens Information website (www.citizensinformation.ie) and search for "Redundancy Pay". You can also contact the National Redundancy Helpline on 1890 80 80 90.

results.ground_truth: You must complete the application form and provide supporting documents. You can apply for most payments online. You can also get an application form from your local Intreo Centre or Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre. You can also get an application form on gov.ie. Your Intreo Centre, Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre can help you fill in your application form. Birth certs for social welfare You are no longer required to provide copies of birth certificates for social welfare purposes if you were born in Ireland and your birth is in the Register of Births. The Department of Social Protection can access this information directly. You can get more information about getting a Birth, Marriage or Death certificate.
results.question: How to apply for social welfare?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How to apply for social welfare?

Helpful Answer:

To apply for social welfare in Ireland, you can follow these steps:

1. Gather your documents: You will need a PPS number, proof of identity, proof of address, and any other relevant documents such as bank statements or proof of income.

2. Fill out the application form: You can get the application form from your local Social Welfare Office or download it from the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection's website.

3. Submit your application: You can submit your completed application form and supporting documents in person at your local Social Welfare Office, or by post.

4. Wait for a decision: The processing time for social welfare applications can vary, but you should receive a decision within a few weeks. If you need to provide more information, the Social Welfare Office will contact you.

5. If approved, you will receive your payment: If your application is approved, you will start receiving your social welfare payment on the date specified in your approval letter.

For more information, you can visit the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection's website or contact your local Social Welfare Office.

results.ground_truth: You must make comments about planning applications in writing to the local authority where the application was made. You may be able to do this on your local authority's website. If possible, you should quote the planning application's reference number. You must also give your: Name Address Phone number Email address (if you have one)
results.question: How can I comment on a planning application?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How can I comment on a planning application?

Helpful Answer:

To comment on a planning application in Ireland, you can follow these steps:

1. Check the local authority's website for planning applications. Each local authority has its own website where planning applications are published.

2. Find the planning application you wish to comment on. You can search for applications by address, application number, or by checking the weekly list of new applications.

3. Register for an account on the local authority's online planning portal, if you haven't already. This will allow you to submit your comments online.

4. Submit your comments. When submitting your comments, make sure to include your name and address, as these will be made public. Your comments should be relevant to the planning application and should be based on factual information.

5. Send a copy of your submission to the applicant, if you wish. This is not required, but it may help the applicant understand your concerns and allow for a more productive dialogue.

6. Keep a record of your submission. This will help you track the progress of the planning application and any decisions made by the local authority.

For more information, you can visit the Citizen's Information website at <https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/housing/planning/making_a_submission_on_a_planning_application.html> or contact your local authority's planning department.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration
results.question: What is the Citizens Information Service?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the Citizens Information Service?

Helpful Answer:

The Citizens Information Service (CIS) is a free, impartial, and confidential service that provides information, advice, and advocacy on a wide range of social services, government departments, and public bodies in Ireland. The service aims to help people understand their rights, entitlements, and obligations, and to support them in accessing the services they need.

The CIS operates through a network of Citizens Information Centres located throughout the country, as well as a national call centre, a website, and a mobile app. The service is funded by the Irish Government and is independent of all political parties and government departments.

The CIS provides information on a wide range of topics, including social welfare, housing, health, education, employment, taxation, consumer rights, and immigration. The service also provides advocacy support to help people navigate complex systems and resolve issues with public bodies.

The CIS is committed to promoting equality, human rights, and social inclusion, and to ensuring that everyone has access to the information and support they need to live a full and active life in Ireland.

results.ground_truth: People aged between 18 and 24 and: Had been out of work and getting a qualifying payment (see below) for at least 12 months or Faced a significant barrier to work (if unemployed for less than 12 months) What were the qualifying payments? You must have been getting one of the following payments for at least 12 months: Jobseeker's Benefit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Jobseeker's Transitional payment, One-Parent Family Payment, Disability Allowance, Blind Person’s Pension, or Supplementary Welfare Allowance. Other schemes that counted towards the qualifying period The 12-month qualifying period could also have included time spent on schemes such as: SOLAS training apprenticeships, Youthreach, Back to Education Allowance, Fastrack to Information Technology and Tús.
results.question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?

Helpful Answer:
The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) was a government initiative aimed at providing employment and training opportunities for young people aged 18-24 who were not in education, employment, or training (NEET). To be eligible for YESS, individuals must have been:

1. Irish or EU citizens, or have been granted permission to reside in Ireland.
2. Aged between 18 and 24 years old.
3. Unemployed or economically inactive (not in education, employment, or training).
4. Not in receipt of any other employment or training support.

Please note that YESS has been replaced by the Tús scheme, which offers part-time employment opportunities for unemployed individuals who are in receipt of certain social welfare payments. For more information on the Tús scheme, please visit the Citizens Information website or contact your local Intreo Centre.
results.answer:
The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) was a government initiative aimed at providing employment and training opportunities for young people aged 18-24 who were not in education, employment, or training (NEET). To be eligible for YESS, individuals must have been:

- Irish or EU citizens, or have been granted permission to reside in Ireland.
- Aged between 18 and 24 years old.
- Unemployed or economically inactive (not in education, employment, or training).
- Not in receipt of any other employment or training support.

Please note that YESS has been replaced by the Tús scheme, which offers part-time employment opportunities for unemployed individuals who are in receipt of certain social welfare payments. For more information on the Tús scheme, please visit the Citizens Information website or contact your local Intreo Centre.

results.ground_truth: If you are a carer you may need to take breaks. Respite care is when you can take a break from caring, and the person you care for is looked after by someone else. It can be covered by family members or an organisation so you can take a short break, a holiday or a rest. Respite care can be for carers of older people or people with different disabilities. Respite care can cover different lengths of time such as: A very short time, for example for an evening Or a much longer arrangement, for example for a holiday Respite care schemes are sometimes called 'Breakaway' or 'Friendship' schemes.
results.question: What is respite care?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is respite care?

Helpful Answer:

Respite care is a short-term break for a person who usually provides care for a family member or a person with a disability. This service allows the primary caregiver to rest, take a vacation, or handle personal matters without worrying about the care of the person they are caring for. Respite care can be provided in the person's own home, in a day care center, or in a residential facility. It is an important service that helps to maintain the health and well-being of both the caregiver and the person receiving care.

For more information on respite care services in Ireland, you can visit the Citizen's Information website at: https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/health_services_and_supports/respite_care.html or contact your local Health Service Executive (HSE) office.

results.ground_truth: If you have a medical card, you can get certain health services free of charge. Usually, your dependent spouse or partner and your children can also get the same range of health services for free. Your medical card is issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE).
results.question: What is a medical card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a medical card?

Helpful Answer:

A Medical Card is a document issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE) in Ireland that entitles the holder to free public healthcare services, including GP visits, hospital services, and prescription medicines. To be eligible for a Medical Card, you must meet certain income and means-tested criteria. There are also GP Visit Cards available for those who do not qualify for a Medical Card but still need assistance with the cost of GP visits. For more information, visit the Citizens Information website or contact the HSE directly.

results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.
results.question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?

Helpful Answer:

In Ireland, pre-nuptial agreements, also known as pre-marital agreements, are not legally binding. However, they can be taken into account by the courts when deciding on the division of assets in the event of a divorce. The courts have the power to set aside any agreement that is deemed unfair or unreasonable. It's important to note that both parties must have received independent legal advice before the agreement is signed, and full disclosure of assets is required. For more detailed information, I would recommend visiting the Citizens Information website or consulting a legal professional.
results.answer: In Ireland, pre-nuptial agreements, also known as pre-marital agreements, are not legally binding. However, they can be taken into account by the courts when deciding on the division of assets in the event of a divorce. The courts have the power to set aside any agreement that is deemed unfair or unreasonable. It's important to note that both parties must have received independent legal advice before the agreement is signed, and full disclosure of assets is required. For more detailed information, I would recommend visiting the Citizens Information website or consulting a legal professional.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.
results.question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:

The Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) is the body responsible for the regulation of aviation in Ireland. The IAA is an independent statutory body, established under the Irish Aviation Authority Act 1993. It is responsible for the safety, security, and regularity of civil aviation in Ireland. This includes the regulation of airports, air traffic services, and the licensing of aircraft and airline operators. For more information, you can visit the IAA's website at www.iaa.ie.
results.answer: The Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) is the body responsible for the regulation of aviation in Ireland. The IAA is an independent statutory body, established under the Irish Aviation Authority Act 1993. It is responsible for the safety, security, and regularity of civil aviation in Ireland. This includes the regulation of airports, air traffic services, and the licensing of aircraft and airline operators. For more information, you can visit the IAA's website at www.iaa.ie.

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.
results.question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Helpful Answer:

The Cycle to Work Scheme is a government-approved initiative that encourages employees to use healthier and more environmentally friendly methods of transportation by providing tax incentives for purchasing bicycles and related equipment. Under this scheme, employers can provide bicycles and cycling equipment to their employees as a tax-free benefit. The employee pays for the bike through salary sacrifice, which means they agree to give up part of their salary in exchange for the bike. This arrangement results in significant savings for the employee, as the cost of the bike is not subject to income tax, Universal Social Charge (USC), or the employee's Class of Income Tax (COIT). The employer also benefits from reduced National Insurance contributions. The maximum value of the bike and equipment that can be provided under the scheme is €1,250, and the employee must repay the full cost of the bike within 12 to 24 months.
results.answer: The Cycle to Work Scheme is a government-approved initiative that encourages employees to use healthier and more environmentally friendly methods of transportation by providing tax incentives for purchasing bicycles and related equipment. Under this scheme, employers can provide bicycles and cycling equipment to their employees as a tax-free benefit. The employee pays for the bike through salary sacrifice, which means they agree to give up part of their salary in exchange for the bike. The employer also benefits from reduced National Insurance contributions. The maximum value of the bike and equipment that can be provided under the scheme is €1,250, and the employee must repay the full cost of the bike within 12 to 24 months.

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. There are electronic displays telling you the time of the next tram at every Luas stop. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.
results.question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?

Helpful Answer:

The Luas, Dublin's light rail system, operates daily from early morning until late evening. The exact operating hours may vary depending on the day of the week and the time of year.

The Luas Red Line runs every 5-7 minutes during peak hours and every 10-15 minutes during off-peak hours. The Luas Green Line runs every 6-8 minutes during peak hours and every 10-15 minutes during off-peak hours.

For the most accurate and up-to-date information, please visit the Luas website (www.luas.ie) or contact their customer service line at +353 1 873 4222.
